Good afternoon,
 
This is Russ Mitchell filling in for Katie while she
  is on assignment. 
 
The Georgia
  man who might have exposed trans-Atlantic flight passengers and crewmembers
  to a drug-resistant form of tuberculosis is in isolation and is headed to Denver for treatment.
  His travels have triggered an international search for people who might have
  been exposed to the potentially fatal disease. Kelly Cobiella will piece
  together details of this man’s travels and Nancy Cordes will explain
  more about drug-resistant tuberculosis – and tell you where else in the
  world it can be found.
 
Lara Logan will have more of her exclusive interview
  with Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki in which he admits there is a real threat
  of a coup in Iraq.
  
 
Controversy is raging over a reality TV show in the Netherlands.
  It will have just three contestants and the winner will walk away with a
  … kidney. A 37-year-old woman dying of cancer is giving away a healthy
  kidney to one of three people in need of a transplant. Richard Roth reports
  that the TV station says there’s a good reason for showing a program
  even they admit is “tasteless.”
 
Here in the United States, the five-year-old
  No Child Left Behind law is up for debate this year and it’s time for a
  report card. Under the legislation, schools are judged based on the way their
  state decides to test students – and for stricter states, that leaves
  pressure to ease up just to fit in. Tonight, Kelly Wallace will have a look
  at how some states’ test scores look on paper – and why they
  don’t always measure up.
 
And Kimberly Dozier will bring you to the
  “other front line” of the battle for Iraq. She’ll talk to the
  medics and caregivers that fight to save wounded soldiers – and who
  often serve as a lifeline for the victim. Kimberly will also tell more of her
  own story of recovery.
 
Please join us for this and more,
 




Russ Mitchell
CouricandCo@cbs.com
